hedline.hl1: Sit on a Bench And Read a Book

abstract.p: Article suggests several garden-themed mystery novels by Ann Ripley (S)

block.p: There comes a time when even the most devoted gardener has to take a rest. Ease the guilt of not working in the yard (if you feel any) by lying in a hammock or sitting on the beach with one of Ann Ripley's garden-themed mysteries.

Beginning with ''Death of a Garden Pest'' (Bantam Books, 1997), and continuing through the recently released ''The Perennial Killer'' (Bantam), Ms. Ripley chronicles the crime-solving ways of her sleuth, Louise Eldridge, who is the host of a PBS gardening show.

There comes a time when even the most devoted gardener has to take a rest. Ease the guilt of not working in the yard (if you feel any) by lying in a hammock or sitting on the beach with one of Ann Ripley's garden-themed mysteries.

Beginning with ''Death of a Garden Pest'' (Bantam Books, 1997), and continuing through the recently released ''The Perennial Killer'' (Bantam), Ms. Ripley chronicles the crime-solving ways of her sleuth, Louise Eldridge, who is the host of a PBS gardening show.

Large dollops of garden history and information are interspersed throughout all five of the Louise Eldridge mysteries, such as ''Death of a Political Plant'' (Bantam, 1998), which deals with nefarious goings-on in Washington, D.C.
